respondents: Claimants Against the Fund Comprising the Proceeds of the Sale of the M.V "Jade Transporter"

sections.facts: The case arose from the collapse of the Eddie Steamship group, a collection of ship‑owning companies controlled by W H Eddie Hsu. Several vessels in the group – notably the m.v. Jade Transporter – were arrested in the Durban and Coast Local Division to enforce various maritime claims (fuel, lubricants, mortgages, etc.). The vessel was eventually sold by public auction on 18 September 1984, producing US$5.71 million, which was held as a fund in the court. A referee was appointed to determine and rank the competing claims against that fund. The referee distinguished between "direct" claims (arising in respect of the Jade Transporter itself) and "associated" claims (arising in respect of other ships that were considered associated with the Jade Transporter under the Admiralty Jurisdiction Regulation Act 105 of 1983). Hollandsche Bank‑Unie (HBU) sought to have the fund distributed according to section 11 of the Act, arguing that section 11(8) gave priority to direct claims over associated‑ship claims. The lower court interpreted the provision differently, leading to an appeal before the Supreme Court of Appeal.
sections.issues: 1. How should section 11(8) of the Admiralty Jurisdiction Regulation Act 105 of 1983 be interpreted – in particular, whether it applies only when the fund arises from an action in rem against an associated ship, and whether it creates a two‑queue system giving priority to direct claims over associated‑ship claims. 2. Whether claims falling under section 11(1)(c)(v) (necessaries of the ship) should be placed in the first queue irrespective of whether they are direct or associated‑ship claims. 3. Whether a distinction should be drawn between claims arising against a sister ship (directly owned) and a group ship (indirectly owned) for ranking purposes.
sections.principles: The Court applied rules of statutory interpretation, favoring the ordinary grammatical meaning of the words unless such meaning would lead to an absurd result. It considered the purposive approach but rejected a broad amendment of the preamble to "any claim against" the fund, finding no authority for such a radical rewrite. The Court relied on precedent (e.g., Euromarine International) for the meaning of section 11(8) and upheld the principle that the provision creates two distinct queues: first, claims "in respect of" the associated ship, and second, claims "in respect of" the ship concerned. The Court also affirmed that section 11(1)(c)(v) does not receive a special priority and falls into the second queue when the fund arises from an associated‑ship action.
sections.application: The Supreme Court held that the literal wording of section 11(8) is sufficient and that the provision applies where the fund arises by reason of an action in rem against an associated ship. It therefore rejected the appellant’s (Summit) argument for a separate rider to place sister‑ship claims in the first queue. The Court confirmed the lower court’s order that direct claims on the Jade Transporter take priority over associated‑ship claims, and that there is no differentiation between sister and group ships for ranking purposes. The Court also upheld the earlier ruling that necessaries‑man claims do not receive special priority and belong to the second queue.
sections.conclusion: The appeal by Summit Industrial Corporation was dismissed with costs. The order confirming that claims of Gulf Oil Trading Co, Scallop Petroleum Co and Summit Industrial Corporation in respect of supplies to ships other than the Jade Transporter rank for payment under section 11(8) after the direct claims on the Jade Transporter was upheld. Costs were awarded to Hollandsche Bank‑Unie as against the Fund.
